comments: This course is designed as the first half of a two-semester intermediate sequence designed to help students attain a level of proficiency that should allow them to function comfortably in a French-speaking environment. Students are expected to have already learned the most basic grammatical structures in elementary French and are expected to review these independently outside of class. This course builds on existing French skills and increase students’ confidence and ability to read, write, speak, and understand French. Also, the course introduces students to more complex grammatical structures and more challenging cultural material.  All the students found that the class was “really interesting” and “great.” The reviews allowed students to learn the history and gave “a very comprehensive overview of French history up until the revolution.” Students “enjoyed” and “loved” this course.  Professor Donaldson-Evans was called “wonderful,” “engaging,” “funny” and “one of the best teachers.” Students were impressed by his knowledge of the subject and his ability to communicate the material well. He “cares about students,” said one. Also, one student found that he was extremely “easy to get a hold of” and very “understanding.”  One student recommended this course “to any major, and any non-major who is fluent in French and interested in history.” The course requires reading, online, workbook, and audio materials, along with writing practice. Although students found that “the style of lecturing wasn’t really conducive to class participation,” students found that overall, they learned a great deal of material through this course.  (This review is based on the seven student comments which were submitted.)
